body.p:
To His Excellency Thomas E Bramlett,
Govenor of Kentucky: --

Your petitioner, J. R. Rice, respectfully represents and states that at the April term, 1860, of the Mercer Circuit Court, he was fined, by a Jury, sixty dollars for on the charge of selling a drink of whiskey to one P. M. Hale: that at that time your petitioner had license to sell in quantities not less than a quart, and he further states that the drink of whisky for which he was fined was sold to said Hale while your petitioner was absent in another county, by a young man who was for him -- that it was done contrary to the directions and order of your petitioner -- that it was contrary to the practice in his house and done without any knowledge or approval on his part -- He further states that he gave his clerk a positive command not to sell in less than the legal quantity --

Your petitioner further says that at the time the fine was imposed he was necessarily absent from the county, and having been assured that the case would be continued had no opportunity to make a defence -- For these reasons he would most respectfully ask your Excellency to remit his fine --

State of Kentucky
Mercer County } Sct --

J. R. Rice says on oath that the
statements in the foregoing petition are true --
Subscribed and sworn to before me as Police Judge of Harrodsburg, this 13 day of August 1863
John G. Kyle P. J. H.
We the undersigned persons residents of Mercer County join in the prayer of J. R. Rice for the remission of his fine
